column2: CHAPTER VIII.
column3: CHAPTER eight.

column2: How each of them knew other, and of their great courtesy, and how his brother Sir Ector came unto him, and of their joy.
column3: How each of them knew other, and of their great courtesy, and how his brother Sir Ector came unto him, and of their joy.

column2: AND therewithal Sir Launcelot kneeled down upon his knees, and threw away his shield and his sword from him.
column3: AND therewithal Sir Launcelot kneeled down upon his knees, and threw away his shield and his sword from him.

column2: When Sir Percivale saw him do so he marvelled what he meant.
column3: When Sir Percivale saw him do so he marvelled what he meant.

column2: And then thus he said: Sir knight, whatsomever thou be, I require thee upon the high order of knighthood, tell me thy true name.
column3: And then thus he said: Sir knight, whatsomever thou be, I require thee upon the high order of knighthood, tell me thy true name.

column2: Then he said: So God me help, my name is Sir Launcelot du Lake, King Ban's son of Benoy.
column3: Then he said: So God me help, my name is Sir Launcelot du Lake, King Ban's son of Benoy.

column2: Alas, said Sir Percivale, what have I done?
column3: Alas, said Sir Percivale, what have I done?

column2: I was sent by the queen for to seek you, and so I have sought you nigh this two year, and yonder is Sir Ector de Maris, your brother abideth me on the other side of the yonder water.
column3: I was sent by the queen for to seek you, and so I have sought you nigh this two year, and yonder is Sir Ector de Maris, your brother abideth me on the other side of the yonder water.

column2: Now for God's sake, said Sir Percivale, forgive me mine offences that I have here done.
column3: Now for God's sake, said Sir Percivale, forgive me mine offences that I have here done.

column2: It is soon forgiven, said Sir Launcelot.
column3: It is soon forgiven, said Sir Launcelot.

column2: Then Sir Percivale sent for Sir Ector de Maris, and when Sir Launcelot had a sight of him, he ran unto him and took him in his arms; and then Sir Ector kneeled down, and either wept upon other, that all had pity to behold them.
column3: Then Sir Percivale sent for Sir Ector de Maris, and when Sir Launcelot had a sight of him, he ran unto him and took him in his arms; and then Sir Ector kneeled down, and either wept upon other, that all had pity to behold them.

column2: Then came Dame Elaine and she there made them great cheer as might lie in her power; and there she told Sir Ector and Sir Percivale how and in what manner Sir Launcelot came into that country, and how he was healed; and there it was known how long Sir Launcelot was with Sir Bliant and with Sir Selivant, and how he first met with them, and how he departed from them because of a boar; and how the hermit healed Sir Launcelot of his great wound, and how that he came to Corbin.
column3: Then came Dame Elaine and she there made them great cheer as might lie in her power; and there she told Sir Ector and Sir Percivale how and in what manner Sir Launcelot came into that country, and how he was healed; and there it was known how long Sir Launcelot was with Sir Bliant and with Sir Selivant, and how he first met with them, and how he departed from them because of a boar; and how the hermit healed Sir Launcelot of his great wound, and how that he came to Corbin.

column2: CHAPTER IX.
column3: CHAPTER nine.

column2: How Sir Bors and Sir Lionel came to King Brandegore, and how Sir Bors took his son Helin le Blank, and of Sir Launcelot.
column3: How Sir Bors and Sir Lionel came to King Brandegore, and how Sir Bors took his son Helin le Blank, and of Sir Launcelot.

column2: NOW leave we Sir Launcelot in the Joyous Isle with the Lady Dame Elaine, and Sir Percivale and Sir Ector playing with them, and turn we to Sir Bors de Ganis and Sir Lionel, that had sought Sir Launcelot nigh by the space of two year, and never could they hear of him.
column3: NOW leave we Sir Launcelot in the Joyous Isle with the Lady Dame Elaine, and Sir Percivale and Sir Ector playing with them, and turn we to Sir Bors de Ganis and Sir Lionel, that had sought Sir Launcelot nigh by the space of two year, and never could they hear of him.

column2: And as they thus rode, by adventure they came to the house of Brandegore, and there Sir Bors was well known, for he had gotten a child upon the king's daughter fifteen year to-fore, and his name was Helin le Blank.
column3: And as they thus rode, by adventure they came to the house of Brandegore, and there Sir Bors was well known, for he had gotten a child upon the king's daughter fifteen year to fore, and his name was Helin le Blank.

column2: And when Sir Bors saw that child it liked him passing well.
column3: And when Sir Bors saw that child it liked him passing well.

column2: And so those knights had good cheer of the King Brandegore.
column3: And so those knights had good cheer of the King Brandegore.

column2: And on the morn Sir Bors came afore King Brandegore and said: Here is my son Helin le Blank, that as it is said he is my son; and sith it is so, I will that ye wit that I will have him with me unto the court of King Arthur.
column3: And on the morn Sir Bors came afore King Brandegore and said: Here is my son Helin le Blank, that as it is said he is my son; and sith it is so, I will that ye wit that I will have him with me unto the court of King Arthur.

column2: Sir, said the king, ye may well take him with you, but he is over tender of age.
column3: Sir, said the king, ye may well take him with you, but he is over tender of age.

column2: As for that, said Sir Bors, I will have him with me, and bring him to the house of most worship of the world.
column3: As for that, said Sir Bors, I will have him with me, and bring him to the house of most worship of the world.

column2: So when Sir Bors should depart there was made great sorrow for the departing of Helin le Blank, and great weeping was there made.
column3: So when Sir Bors should depart there was made great sorrow for the departing of Helin le Blank, and great weeping was there made.

column2: But Sir Bors and Sir Lionel departed, and within a while they came to Camelot, where was King Arthur.
column3: But Sir Bors and Sir Lionel departed, and within a while they came to Camelot, where was King Arthur.

column2: And when King Arthur understood that Helin le Blank was Sir Bors' son, and nephew unto King Brandegore, then King Arthur let him make knight of the Round Table; and so he proved a good knight and an adventurous.
column3: And when King Arthur understood that Helin le Blank was Sir Bors' son, and nephew unto King Brandegore, then King Arthur let him make knight of the Round Table; and so he proved a good knight and an adventurous.

column2: Now will we turn to our matter of Sir Launcelot.
column3: Now will we turn to our matter of Sir Launcelot.

column2: It befell upon a day Sir Ector and Sir Percivale came to Sir Launcelot and asked him what he would do, and whether he would go with them unto King Arthur or not.
column3: It befell upon a day Sir Ector and Sir Percivale came to Sir Launcelot and asked him what he would do, and whether he would go with them unto King Arthur or not.

column2: Nay, said Sir Launcelot, that may not be by no mean, for I was so entreated at the court that I cast me never to come there more.
column3: Nay, said Sir Launcelot, that may not be by no mean, for I was so entreated at the court that I cast me never to come there more.

column2: Sir, said Sir Ector, I am your brother, and ye are the man in the world that I love most; and if I understood that it were your disworship, ye may understand I would never counsel you thereto; but King Arthur and all his knights, and in especial Queen Guenever, made such dole and sorrow that it was marvel to hear and see.
column3: Sir, said Sir Ector, I am your brother, and ye are the man in the world that I love most; and if I understood that it were your disworship, ye may understand I would never counsel you thereto; but King Arthur and all his knights, and in especial Queen Guenever, made such dole and sorrow that it was marvel to hear and see.

column2: And ye must remember the great worship and renown that ye be of, how that ye have been more spoken of than any other knight that is now living; for there is none that beareth the name now but ye and Sir Tristram.
column3: And ye must remember the great worship and renown that ye be of, how that ye have been more spoken of than any other knight that is now living; for there is none that beareth the name now but ye and Sir Tristram.

column2: Therefore brother, said Sir Ector, make you ready to ride to the court with us, and I dare say there was never knight better welcome to the court than ye; and I wot well and can make it good, said Sir Ector, it hath cost my lady, the queen, twenty thousand pound the seeking of you.
column3: Therefore brother, said Sir Ector, make you ready to ride to the court with us, and I dare say there was never knight better welcome to the court than ye; and I wot well and can make it good, said Sir Ector, it hath cost my lady, the queen, twenty thousand pound the seeking of you.

column2: Well brother, said Sir Launcelot, I will do after your counsel, and ride with you.
column3: Well brother, said Sir Launcelot, I will do after your counsel, and ride with you.

column2: So then they took their horses and made them ready, and took their leave at King Pelles and at Dame Elaine.
column3: So then they took their horses and made them ready, and took their leave at King Pelles and at Dame Elaine.

column2: And when Sir Launcelot should depart Dame Elaine made great sorrow.
column3: And when Sir Launcelot should depart Dame Elaine made great sorrow.

column2: My lord, Sir Launcelot, said Dame Elaine, at this same feast of Pentecost shall your son and mine, Galahad, be made knight, for he is fully now fifteen winter old.
column3: My lord, Sir Launcelot, said Dame Elaine, at this same feast of Pentecost shall your son and mine, Galahad, be made knight, for he is fully now fifteen winter old.

column2: Do as ye list, said Sir Launcelot; God give him grace to prove a good knight.
column3: Do as ye list, said Sir Launcelot; God give him grace to prove a good knight.

column2: As for that, said Dame Elaine, I doubt not he shall prove the best man of his kin except one.
column3: As for that, said Dame Elaine, I doubt not he shall prove the best man of his kin except one.

column2: Then shall he be a man good enough, said Sir Launcelot.
column3: Then shall he be a man good enough, said Sir Launcelot.

column2: CHAPTER X. How Sir Launcelot with Sir Percivale and Sir Ector came to the court, and of the great joy of him.
column3: CHAPTER ten How Sir Launcelot with Sir Percivale and Sir Ector came to the court, and of the great joy of him.

column2: THEN they departed, and within five days' journey they came to Camelot, that is called in English, Winchester.
column3: THEN they departed, and within five days' journey they came to Camelot, that is called in English, Winchester.

column2: And when Sir Launcelot was come among them, the king and all the knights made great joy of him.
column3: And when Sir Launcelot was come among them, the king and all the knights made great joy of him.

column2: And there Sir Percivale de Galis and Sir Ector de Maris began and told the whole adventures: that Sir Launcelot had been out of his mind the time of his absence, and how he called himself Le Chevaler Mal Fet, the knight that had trespassed; and in three days Sir Launcelot smote down five hundred knights.
column3: And there Sir Percivale de Galis and Sir Ector de Maris began and told the whole adventures: that Sir Launcelot had been out of his mind the time of his absence, and how he called himself Le Chevaler Mal Fet, the knight that had trespassed; and in three days Sir Launcelot smote down five hundred knights.

column2: And ever as Sir Ector and Sir Percivale told these tales of Sir Launcelot, Queen Guenever wept as she should have died. Then the queen made great cheer.
column3: And ever as Sir Ector and Sir Percivale told these tales of Sir Launcelot, Queen Guenever wept as she should have died. Then the queen made great cheer.

column2: O Jesu, said King Arthur, I marvel for what cause ye, Sir Launcelot, went out of your mind.
column3: O Jesu, said King Arthur, I marvel for what cause ye, Sir Launcelot, went out of your mind.

column2: I and many others deem it was for the love of fair Elaine, the daughter of King Pelles, by whom ye are noised that ye have gotten a child, and his name is Galahad, and men say he shall do marvels.
column3: I and many others deem it was for the love of fair Elaine, the daughter of King Pelles, by whom ye are noised that ye have gotten a child, and his name is Galahad, and men say he shall do marvels.

column2: My lord, said Sir Launcelot, if I did any folly I have that I sought.
column3: My lord, said Sir Launcelot, if I did any folly I have that I sought.

column2: And therewithal the king spake no more. But all Sir Launcelot's kin knew for whom he went out of his mind.
column3: And therewithal the king spake no more. But all Sir Launcelot's kin knew for whom he went out of his mind.

column2: And then there were great feasts made and great joy; and many great lords and ladies, when they heard that Sir Launcelot was come to the court again, they made great joy.
column3: And then there were great feasts made and great joy; and many great lords and ladies, when they heard that Sir Launcelot was come to the court again, they made great joy.

column2: CHAPTER XI.
column3: CHAPTER eleven.

column2: How La Beale Isoud counselled Sir Tristram to go unto the court, to the great feast of Pentecost.
column3: How La Beale Isoud counselled Sir Tristram to go unto the court, to the great feast of Pentecost.

column2: NOW will we leave off this matter, and speak we of Sir Tristram, and of Sir Palomides that was the Saracen unchristened.
column3: NOW will we leave off this matter, and speak we of Sir Tristram, and of Sir Palomides that was the Saracen unchristened.

column2: When Sir Tristram was come home unto Joyous Gard from his adventures, all this while that Sir Launcelot was thus missed, two year and more, Sir Tristram bare the renown through all the realm of Logris, and many strange adventures befell him, and full well and manly and worshipfully he brought them to an end.
column3: When Sir Tristram was come home unto Joyous Gard from his adventures, all this while that Sir Launcelot was thus missed, two year and more, Sir Tristram bare the renown through all the realm of Logris, and many strange adventures befell him, and full well and manly and worshipfully he brought them to an end.

column2: So when he was come home La Beale Isoud told him of the great feast that should be at Pentecost next following, and there she told him how Sir Launcelot had been missed two year, and all that while he had been out of his mind, and how he was holpen by the holy vessel, the Sangreal.
column3: So when he was come home La Beale Isoud told him of the great feast that should be at Pentecost next following, and there she told him how Sir Launcelot had been missed two year, and all that while he had been out of his mind, and how he was holpen by the holy vessel, the Sangreal.

column2: Alas, said Sir Tristram, that caused some debate betwixt him and Queen Guenever.
column3: Alas, said Sir Tristram, that caused some debate betwixt him and Queen Guenever.

column2: Sir, said Dame Isoud, I know it all, for Queen Guenever sent me a letter in the which she wrote me all how it was, for to require you to seek him.
column3: Sir, said Dame Isoud, I know it all, for Queen Guenever sent me a letter in the which she wrote me all how it was, for to require you to seek him.

column2: And now, blessed be God, said La Beale Isoud, he is whole and sound and come again to the court.
column3: And now, blessed be God, said La Beale Isoud, he is whole and sound and come again to the court.

column2: Thereof am I glad, said Sir Tristram, and now shall ye and I make us ready, for both ye and I will be at the feast.
column3: Thereof am I glad, said Sir Tristram, and now shall ye and I make us ready, for both ye and I will be at the feast.

column2: Sir, said Isoud, an it please you I will not be there, for through me ye be marked of many good knights, and that caused you to have much more labour for my sake than needeth you.
column3: Sir, said Isoud, an it please you I will not be there, for through me ye be marked of many good knights, and that caused you to have much more labour for my sake than needeth you.

column2: Then will I not be there, said Sir Tristram, but if ye be there.
column3: Then will I not be there, said Sir Tristram, but if ye be there.

column2: God defend, said La Beale Isoud, for then shall I be spoken of shame among all queens and ladies of estate; for ye that are called one of the noblest knights of the world, and ye a knight of the Round Table, how may ye be missed at that feast?
column3: God defend, said La Beale Isoud, for then shall I be spoken of shame among all queens and ladies of estate; for ye that are called one of the noblest knights of the world, and ye a knight of the Round Table, how may ye be missed at that feast?

column2: What shall be said among all knights?
column3: What shall be said among all knights?

column2: See how Sir Tristram hunteth, and hawketh, and cowereth within a castle with his lady, and forsaketh your worship.
column3: See how Sir Tristram hunteth, and hawketh, and cowereth within a castle with his lady, and forsaketh your worship.

column2: Alas, shall some say, it is pity that ever he was made knight, or that ever he should have the love of a lady.
column3: Alas, shall some say, it is pity that ever he was made knight, or that ever he should have the love of a lady.

column2: Also what shall queens and ladies say of me? It is pity that I have my life, that I will hold so noble a knight as ye are from his worship.
column3: Also what shall queens and ladies say of me? It is pity that I have my life, that I will hold so noble a knight as ye are from his worship.

column2: So God me help, said Sir Tristram unto La Beale Isoud, it is passing well said of you and nobly counselled; and now I well understand that ye love me; and like as ye have counselled me I will do a part thereafter.
column3: So God me help, said Sir Tristram unto La Beale Isoud, it is passing well said of you and nobly counselled; and now I well understand that ye love me; and like as ye have counselled me I will do a part thereafter.

column2: But there shall no man nor child ride with me, but myself.
column3: But there shall no man nor child ride with me, but myself.

column2: And so will I ride on Tuesday next coming, and no more harness of war but my spear and my sword.
column3: And so will I ride on Tuesday next coming, and no more harness of war but my spear and my sword.

column2: CHAPTER XII.
column3: CHAPTER twelve.

column2: How Sir Tristram departed unarmed and met with Sir Palomides, and how they smote each other, and how Sir Palomides forbare him.
column3: How Sir Tristram departed unarmed and met with Sir Palomides, and how they smote each other, and how Sir Palomides forbare him.

column2: AND so when the day came Sir Tristram took his leave at La Beale Isoud, and she sent with him four knights, and within half a mile he sent them again: and within a mile after Sir Tristram saw afore him where Sir Palomides had stricken down a knight, and almost wounded him to the death.
column3: AND so when the day came Sir Tristram took his leave at La Beale Isoud, and she sent with him four knights, and within half a mile he sent them again: and within a mile after Sir Tristram saw afore him where Sir Palomides had stricken down a knight, and almost wounded him to the death.

column2: Then Sir Tristram repented him that he was not armed, and then he hoved still.
column3: Then Sir Tristram repented him that he was not armed, and then he hoved still.

column2: With that Sir Palomides knew Sir Tristram, and cried on high: Sir Tristram, now be we met, for or we depart we will redress our old sores.
column3: With that Sir Palomides knew Sir Tristram, and cried on high: Sir Tristram, now be we met, for or we depart we will redress our old sores.

column2: As for that, said Sir Tristram, there was yet never Christian man might make his boast that ever I fled from him; and wit ye well, Sir Palomides, thou that art a Saracen shall never make thy boast that Sir Tristram de Liones shall flee from thee.
column3: As for that, said Sir Tristram, there was yet never Christian man might make his boast that ever I fled from him; and wit ye well, Sir Palomides, thou that art a Saracen shall never make thy boast that Sir Tristram de Liones shall flee from thee.

column2: And therewith Sir Tristram made his horse to run, and with all his might he came straight upon Sir Palomides, and brast his spear upon him an hundred pieces.
column3: And therewith Sir Tristram made his horse to run, and with all his might he came straight upon Sir Palomides, and brast his spear upon him an hundred pieces.

column2: And forthwithal Sir Tristram drew his sword.
column3: And forthwithal Sir Tristram drew his sword.

column2: And then he turned his horse and struck at Palomides six great strokes upon his helm; and then Sir Palomides stood still, and beheld Sir Tristram, and marvelled of his woodness, and of his folly.
column3: And then he turned his horse and struck at Palomides six great strokes upon his helm; and then Sir Palomides stood still, and beheld Sir Tristram, and marvelled of his woodness, and of his folly.

column2: And then Sir Palomides said to himself: An Sir Tristram were armed, it were hard to cease him of this battle, and if I turn again and slay him I am ashamed wheresomever that I go.
column3: And then Sir Palomides said to himself: An Sir Tristram were armed, it were hard to cease him of this battle, and if I turn again and slay him I am ashamed wheresomever that I go.

column2: Then Sir Tristram spake and said: Thou coward knight, what castest thou to do; why wilt thou not do battle with me? for have thou no doubt I shall endure all thy malice.
column3: Then Sir Tristram spake and said: Thou coward knight, what castest thou to do; why wilt thou not do battle with me? for have thou no doubt I shall endure all thy malice.

column2: Ah, Sir Tristram, said Palomides, full well thou wottest I may not fight with thee for shame, for thou art here naked and I am armed, and if I slay thee, dishonour shall be mine. And well thou wottest, said Sir Palomides to Sir Tristram, I know thy strength and thy hardiness to endure against a good knight.
column3: Ah, Sir Tristram, said Palomides, full well thou wottest I may not fight with thee for shame, for thou art here naked and I am armed, and if I slay thee, dishonour shall be mine. And well thou wottest, said Sir Palomides to Sir Tristram, I know thy strength and thy hardiness to endure against a good knight.

column2: That is truth, said Sir Tristram, I understand thy valiantness well.
column3: That is truth, said Sir Tristram, I understand thy valiantness well.

column2: Ye say well, said Sir Palomides; now, I require you, tell me a question that I shall say to you.
column3: Ye say well, said Sir Palomides; now, I require you, tell me a question that I shall say to you.

column2: Tell me what it is, said Sir Tristram, and I shall answer you the truth, as God me help.
column3: Tell me what it is, said Sir Tristram, and I shall answer you the truth, as God me help.

column2: I put case, said Sir Palomides, that ye were armed at all rights as well as I am, and I naked as ye be, what would you do to me now, by your true knighthood?
column3: I put case, said Sir Palomides, that ye were armed at all rights as well as I am, and I naked as ye be, what would you do to me now, by your true knighthood?

column2: Ah, said Sir Tristram, now I understand thee well, Sir Palomides, for now must I say mine own judgment, and as God me bless, that I shall say shall not be said for no fear that I have of thee.
column3: Ah, said Sir Tristram, now I understand thee well, Sir Palomides, for now must I say mine own judgment, and as God me bless, that I shall say shall not be said for no fear that I have of thee.

column2: But this is all: wit Sir Palomides, as at this time thou shouldest depart from me, for I would not have ado with thee.
column3: But this is all: wit Sir Palomides, as at this time thou shouldest depart from me, for I would not have ado with thee.

column2: No more will I, said Palomides, and therefore ride forth on thy way.
column3: No more will I, said Palomides, and therefore ride forth on thy way.

column2: As for that I may choose, said Sir Tristram, either to ride or to abide.
column3: As for that I may choose, said Sir Tristram, either to ride or to abide.

column2: But Sir Palomides, said Sir Tristram, I marvel of one thing, that thou that art so good a knight, that thou wilt not be christened, and thy brother, Sir Safere, hath been christened many a day.
column3: But Sir Palomides, said Sir Tristram, I marvel of one thing, that thou that art so good a knight, that thou wilt not be christened, and thy brother, Sir Safere, hath been christened many a day.

column2: CHAPTER XIII.
column3: CHAPTER thirteen.

column2: How that Sir Tristram gat him harness of a knight which was hurt, and how he overthrew Sir Palomides.
column3: How that Sir Tristram gat him harness of a knight which was hurt, and how he overthrew Sir Palomides.

column2: AS for that, said Sir Palomides, I may not yet be christened for one avow that I have made many years agone; howbeit in my heart I believe in Jesu Christ and his mild mother Mary; but I have but one battle to do, and when that is done I will be baptised with a good will.
column3: AS for that, said Sir Palomides, I may not yet be christened for one avow that I have made many years agone; howbeit in my heart I believe in Jesu Christ and his mild mother Mary; but I have but one battle to do, and when that is done I will be baptised with a good will.

column2: By my head, said Tristram, as for one battle thou shalt not seek it no longer.
column3: By my head, said Tristram, as for one battle thou shalt not seek it no longer.

column2: For God defend, said Sir Tristram, that through my default thou shouldst longer live thus a Saracen, for yonder is a knight that ye, Sir Palomides, have hurt and smitten down.
column3: For God defend, said Sir Tristram, that through my default thou shouldst longer live thus a Saracen, for yonder is a knight that ye, Sir Palomides, have hurt and smitten down.

column2: Now help me that I were armed in his armour, and I shall soon fulfil thine avows.
column3: Now help me that I were armed in his armour, and I shall soon fulfil thine avows.

column2: As ye will, said Palomides, so it shall be.
column3: As ye will, said Palomides, so it shall be.

column2: So they rode both unto that knight that sat upon a bank, and then Sir Tristram saluted him, and he weakly saluted him again.
column3: So they rode both unto that knight that sat upon a bank, and then Sir Tristram saluted him, and he weakly saluted him again.

column2: Sir knight, said Sir Tristram, I require you tell me your right name.
column3: Sir knight, said Sir Tristram, I require you tell me your right name.

column2: Sir, he said, my name is Sir Galleron of Galway, and knight of the Table Round.
column3: Sir, he said, my name is Sir Galleron of Galway, and knight of the Table Round.

column2: So God me help, said Sir Tristram, I am right heavy of your hurts; but this is all, I must pray you to lend me all your whole armour, for ye see I am unarmed, and I must do battle with this knight.
column3: So God me help, said Sir Tristram, I am right heavy of your hurts; but this is all, I must pray you to lend me all your whole armour, for ye see I am unarmed, and I must do battle with this knight.

column2: Sir, said the hurt knight, ye shall have it with a good will; but ye must beware, for I warn you that knight is wight.
column3: Sir, said the hurt knight, ye shall have it with a good will; but ye must beware, for I warn you that knight is wight.

column2: Sir, said Galleron, I pray you tell me your name, and what is that knight's name that hath beaten me.
column3: Sir, said Galleron, I pray you tell me your name, and what is that knight's name that hath beaten me.

column2: Sir, as for my name it is Sir Tristram de Liones, and as for the knight's name that hath hurt you is Sir Palomides, brother to the good knight Sir Safere, and yet is Sir Palomides unchristened.
column3: Sir, as for my name it is Sir Tristram de Liones, and as for the knight's name that hath hurt you is Sir Palomides, brother to the good knight Sir Safere, and yet is Sir Palomides unchristened.

column2: Alas, said Sir Galleron, that is pity that so good a knight and so noble a man of arms should be unchristened.
column3: Alas, said Sir Galleron, that is pity that so good a knight and so noble a man of arms should be unchristened.

column2: So God me help, said Sir Tristram, either he shall slay me or I him but that he shall be christened or ever we depart in-sunder. My lord Sir Tristram, said Sir Galleron, your renown and worship is well known through many realms, and God save you this day from shenship and shame.
column3: So God me help, said Sir Tristram, either he shall slay me or I him but that he shall be christened or ever we depart in sunder. My lord Sir Tristram, said Sir Galleron, your renown and worship is well known through many realms, and God save you this day from shenship and shame.

column2: Then Sir Tristram unarmed Galleron, the which was a noble knight, and had done many deeds of arms, and he was a large knight of flesh and bone.
column3: Then Sir Tristram unarmed Galleron, the which was a noble knight, and had done many deeds of arms, and he was a large knight of flesh and bone.

column2: And when he was unarmed he stood upon his feet, for he was bruised in the back with a spear; yet so as Sir Galleron might, he armed Sir Tristram.
column3: And when he was unarmed he stood upon his feet, for he was bruised in the back with a spear; yet so as Sir Galleron might, he armed Sir Tristram.

column2: And then Sir Tristram mounted upon his own horse, and in his hand he gat Sir Galleron's spear; and therewithal Sir Palomides was ready.
column3: And then Sir Tristram mounted upon his own horse, and in his hand he gat Sir Galleron's spear; and therewithal Sir Palomides was ready.

column2: And so they came hurtling together, and either smote other in midst of their shields; and therewithal Sir Palomides' spear brake, and Sir Tristram smote down the horse; and Sir Palomides, as soon as he might, avoided his horse, and dressed his shield, and pulled out his sword.
column3: And so they came hurtling together, and either smote other in midst of their shields; and therewithal Sir Palomides' spear brake, and Sir Tristram smote down the horse; and Sir Palomides, as soon as he might, avoided his horse, and dressed his shield, and pulled out his sword.

column2: That saw Sir Tristram, and therewithal he alighted and tied his horse till a tree.
column3: That saw Sir Tristram, and therewithal he alighted and tied his horse till a tree.

column2: CHAPTER XIV.
column3: CHAPTER fourteen.

column2: How Sir Tristram and Sir Palomides fought long together, and after accorded, and how Sir Tristram made him to be christened.
column3: How Sir Tristram and Sir Palomides fought long together, and after accorded, and how Sir Tristram made him to be christened.

column2: AND then they came together as two wild boars, lashing together, tracing and traversing as noble men that oft had been well proved in battle; but ever Sir Palomides dread the might of Sir Tristram, and therefore he suffered him to breathe him.
column3: AND then they came together as two wild boars, lashing together, tracing and traversing as noble men that oft had been well proved in battle; but ever Sir Palomides dread the might of Sir Tristram, and therefore he suffered him to breathe him.

column2: Thus they fought more than two hours, but often Sir Tristram smote such strokes at Sir Palomides that he made him to kneel; and Sir Palomides brake and cut away many pieces of Sir Tristram's shield; and then Sir Palomides wounded Sir Tristram, for he was a well fighting man.
column3: Thus they fought more than two hours, but often Sir Tristram smote such strokes at Sir Palomides that he made him to kneel; and Sir Palomides brake and cut away many pieces of Sir Tristram's shield; and then Sir Palomides wounded Sir Tristram, for he was a well fighting man.

column2: Then Sir Tristram was wood wroth out of measure, and rushed upon Sir Palomides with such a might that Sir Palomides fell grovelling to the earth; and therewithal he leapt up lightly upon his feet, and then Sir Tristram wounded Palomides sore through the shoulder.
column3: Then Sir Tristram was wood wroth out of measure, and rushed upon Sir Palomides with such a might that Sir Palomides fell grovelling to the earth; and therewithal he leapt up lightly upon his feet, and then Sir Tristram wounded Palomides sore through the shoulder.

column2: And ever Sir Tristram fought still in like hard, and Sir Palomides failed not, but gave him many sad strokes.
column3: And ever Sir Tristram fought still in like hard, and Sir Palomides failed not, but gave him many sad strokes.

column2: And at the last Sir Tristram doubled his strokes, and by fortune Sir Tristram smote Sir Palomides sword out of his hand, and if Sir Palomides had stooped for his sword he had been slain.
column3: And at the last Sir Tristram doubled his strokes, and by fortune Sir Tristram smote Sir Palomides sword out of his hand, and if Sir Palomides had stooped for his sword he had been slain.

column2: Then Palomides stood still and beheld his sword with a sorrowful heart. How now, said Sir Tristram unto Palomides, now have I thee at advantage as thou haddest me this day; but it shall never be said in no court, nor among good knights, that Sir Tristram shall slay any knight that is weaponless; and therefore take thou thy sword, and let us make an end of this battle.
column3: Then Palomides stood still and beheld his sword with a sorrowful heart. How now, said Sir Tristram unto Palomides, now have I thee at advantage as thou haddest me this day; but it shall never be said in no court, nor among good knights, that Sir Tristram shall slay any knight that is weaponless; and therefore take thou thy sword, and let us make an end of this battle.

column2: As for to do this battle, said Palomides, I dare right well end it, but I have no great lust to fight no more.
column3: As for to do this battle, said Palomides, I dare right well end it, but I have no great lust to fight no more.

column2: And for this cause, said Palomides: mine offence to you is not so great but that we may be friends.
column3: And for this cause, said Palomides: mine offence to you is not so great but that we may be friends.

column2: All that I have offended is and was for the love of La Beale Isoud.
column3: All that I have offended is and was for the love of La Beale Isoud.

column2: And as for her, I dare say she is peerless above all other ladies, and also I proffered her never no dishonour; and by her I have gotten the most part of my worship.
column3: And as for her, I dare say she is peerless above all other ladies, and also I proffered her never no dishonour; and by her I have gotten the most part of my worship.

column2: And sithen I offended never as to her own person, and as for the offence that I have done, it was against your own person, and for that offence ye have given me this day many sad strokes, and some I have given you again; and now I dare say I felt never man of your might, nor so well breathed, but if it were Sir Launcelot du Lake; wherefore I require you, my lord, forgive me all that I have offended unto you; and this same day have me to the next church, and first let me be clean confessed, and after see you now that I be truly baptised.
column3: And sithen I offended never as to her own person, and as for the offence that I have done, it was against your own person, and for that offence ye have given me this day many sad strokes, and some I have given you again; and now I dare say I felt never man of your might, nor so well breathed, but if it were Sir Launcelot du Lake; wherefore I require you, my lord, forgive me all that I have offended unto you; and this same day have me to the next church, and first let me be clean confessed, and after see you now that I be truly baptised.

column2: And then will we all ride together unto the court of Arthur, that we be there at the high feast.
column3: And then will we all ride together unto the court of Arthur, that we be there at the high feast.

column2: Now take your horse, said Sir Tristram, and as ye say so it shall be, and all thine evil will God forgive it you, and I do.
column3: Now take your horse, said Sir Tristram, and as ye say so it shall be, and all thine evil will God forgive it you, and I do.

column2: And here within this mile is the Suffragan of Carlisle that shall give you the sacrament of baptism.
column3: And here within this mile is the Suffragan of Carlisle that shall give you the sacrament of baptism.

column2: Then they took their horses and Sir Galleron rode with them.
column3: Then they took their horses and Sir Galleron rode with them.

column2: And when they came to the Suffragan Sir Tristram told him their desire.
column3: And when they came to the Suffragan Sir Tristram told him their desire.

column2: Then the Suffragan let fill a great vessel with water, and when he had hallowed it he then confessed clean Sir Palomides, and Sir Tristram and Sir Galleron were his godfathers.
column3: Then the Suffragan let fill a great vessel with water, and when he had hallowed it he then confessed clean Sir Palomides, and Sir Tristram and Sir Galleron were his godfathers.

column2: And then soon after they departed, riding toward Camelot, where King Arthur and Queen Guenever was, and for the most part all the knights of the Round Table.
column3: And then soon after they departed, riding toward Camelot, where King Arthur and Queen Guenever was, and for the most part all the knights of the Round Table.

column2: And so the king and all the court were glad that Sir Palomides was christened.
column3: And so the king and all the court were glad that Sir Palomides was christened.

column2: And at the same feast in came Galahad and sat in the Siege Perilous.
column3: And at the same feast in came Galahad and sat in the Siege Perilous.

column2: And so therewithal departed and dissevered all the knights of the Round Table.
column3: And so therewithal departed and dissevered all the knights of the Round Table.

column2: And Sir Tristram returned again unto Joyous Gard, and Sir Palomides followed the Questing Beast.
column3: And Sir Tristram returned again unto Joyous Gard, and Sir Palomides followed the Questing Beast.

column2: _Here endeth the second book of Sir Tristram that was drawn out of French into English.
column3: underscore Here endeth the second book of Sir Tristram that was drawn out of French into English.

column2: But here is no rehersal of the third book.
column3: But here is no rehersal of the third book.

column2: And here followeth the noble tale of the Sangreal, that called is the Holy Vessel; and the signification of the blessed blood of our Lord Jesus Christ, blessed mote it be, the which was brought into this land by Joseph Aramathie.
column3: And here followeth the noble tale of the Sangreal, that called is the Holy Vessel; and the signification of the blessed blood of our Lord Jesus Christ, blessed mote it be, the which was brought into this land by Joseph Aramathie.

column2: Therefore on all sinful souls blessed Lord have thou mercy.
column3: Therefore on all sinful souls blessed Lord have thou mercy.
